messages: d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:10): Yo, I'm a humble webdesigner and I was reading wikipedia when I got "see also-ed" WHATWG. I'm a litte confused as to why theres a XHTML 2 and a HTML5
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:10): I thought XHTML replaced HTML as like a new version.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:11): d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88: http://blog.whatwg.org/faq/ might help (although it doesn't really cover in detail what you're asking about yet :( ...)
50f88044f12dac51f8a48d6528d71c85 (00:12): d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88: xhtml was never really meant to replace html; it's a common misconception :(
3e1c1074b5072fb0e507ed33291ed9b1 (00:13): maybe here http://xhtml.com/en/future/conversation-with-x-html-5-team/ are some basic principles described
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:14): d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88: but in any case, html5 has an xml serialization as well should you want to use it
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:15): (referred to as xhtml5)
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:15): ic.. well I don't really use any xml
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:16): thank you for the links.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:16): ok. then presumably the xml serialization is less interesting to you than the text/html serialization
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:20): hmm.. I really need to learn about this stuff. Does the w3c decide what can and cant be used for web development?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:20): d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88: does the w3c endorce flash?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:21): s/endorce/endorse/
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:21): ah yeah
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:21): so, what do they do exactly?
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:21): just provide nice buttons for your websites?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:22): "w3c" is mostly a name aiui. then there are many working groups working on different things
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:23): e.g. a new html wg was chartered recently to work on the same thing that the whatwg are working on, basically
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:23): http://www.w3.org/html/wg/
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:24): so two seperate groups are working on the same thing?

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:25): it hasn't been decided formally yet what the htmlwg will be doing, but taking the whatwg proposals as a starting point is the only real proposal that has been put forward
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:25): though the charter is very similar to the whatwg proposals, so presumably that is the intent
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:25): ah ic. so if the whatwg proposal is accepted will they begin working with them?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:26): hopefully it will be one and the same spec with the same editors that are part of both groups
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:27): (i and many others here are members of both groups)
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:28): so whats this for http://www.w3.org/MarkUp/
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:29): d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88: the xhtml2 wg's home page
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:31): yeah but why is there a xhtml2 and a (x)html5

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:33): d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88: because the people in the xhtml2 wg (the old html wg) had a different vision of the future of the web than the vision of opera, mozilla and apple
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:34): So does that mean xhtml2 will never be implemented into a browser?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:35): well, aiui opera, mozilla and apple are not interested in implementing xhtml2
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:35): microsoft have bigger fish to fry
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:36): what do you mean by that? whats microsoft up to?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:36): microsoft are chairing the html wg, but i don't know what their plans are wrt xhtml2 (i would presume they won't implement xhtml2 anytime soon)
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:37): I've never gotten anything to work with IE anyway.
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:38): I signed upto the forums. its a bit of a ghost town. I would of thought it would be full of web developers
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:39): the forums are not so old
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (00:39): but feel free to ask questions there

d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (00:57): yo... this may be a stupid question but in html5 if you just wrote <div> and didn't have a </div> anywhere would it treat it as a void div.. or would it just not work
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:58): It would work the same as in current HTML
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:59): (The whole parsing algorithm is designed to be compatible with what browsers currently implement)
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (01:01): Is it a bad thing to have an empty div? because sometimes (actually quite alot) I use divs purely for presentational purposes
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:02): an empty div for presentational purposes is mostly harmless
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (01:03): mostly...?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:03): but using html for presentational purposes in general is not what html is designed to do
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:03): (...but a <div> without a matching </div> is an error and makes the document non-conforming, regardless of how it's parsed)
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (01:04): so can you write it as "<div>" or does it have to be "<div></div>"
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:04): the latter
d5e0b073765cd0a45ace9f843b8eaf88 (01:04): if theres nothing in it why does it need the </div>
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:05): because otherwise everything after it will be children of the div
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (01:06): e.g. compare "<div>X" with "<div></div>X"
